climbs.name: Exit Planet Mussy
climbs.fa: Russ Walling (TD, 1st pitch 10/97) Bernd Zeugswetter 2nd pitch 2020, In Dust We Trust

content.description:
Pitch 1: Good rock and good edges lull you into thinking you have this one in the bag... then the crux hits you right at the top. Anchors are at a good stance. Single rope rap from here.

Pitch 2: 8 bolts and 11d

Pitch 3: Trivial 5.6 slab to gain the summit. 3 bolts to a rap station.
content.location: Starts left of Blue Balls about 75ft, and left of some really cool slashes on the wall.  Bolt anchors/loweroffs.  Follows the best rock and line up to the anchor.

content.description:
Pitch 1:  Start on a 2 or 3 bolt ladder to gain the main face.  Continue up the slab on thin edges and smears up a seam to a good stance and bolted anchor.

Pitch 2:  A stalled out project with 3 bolts already in.  Wanna try it?
content.location: This route is south of the main face area near the top of the gully.  Walk along the base until you see a short 3 bolt ladder on some black rock that leads to a seam and eventually a left facing shallow corner.  Bolted anchor.

content.description: First Pitch:  Step up and into the corner with a slick start.  Bolts lead all the way up with some interesting moves and a great location.  Don't let the looks of this scare you off if you don't like wide stuff.  It climbs real well as a face climb with just a bit of wiggling.
content.protection: 11+ bolts on both pitches.  Last pitch is 5.6 slab for about 2 moves.  Bolted anchors on pitches #1 and #2, not sure about the topout anchors.
content.location: Blue Balls is the huge left slanting crack feature on the right side of Mussypotamia.  It looks like an OW / Flare, and it just might be..... Bolted anchors, single rope rap.

content.description: Thin face on good rock.  Crux is passing a small rooflet/bulge.  Mostly edges on a slab.
content.location:
Continue up the base from Blue Balls about 50ft and look for the bolts.  This route starts right before a big boulder chokes the base.

Bolted anchors.
